benefits.title: Creatine in Health and Disease
benefits.summary: Creatine supplementation has several health and therapeutic benefits throughout the lifespan, including promoting general health, enhancing cellular metabolism, and helping individuals recover from injury and manage chronic disease.

benefits.title: THE EFFECTS OF ACUTE CREATINE SUPPLEMENTATION ON MULTIPLE SPRINT CYCLING AND RUNNING PERFORMANCE IN RUGBY PLAYERS
benefits.summary: Acute creatine supplementation in rugby players showed small improvements in performance, but no significant differences were found in terms of power output, running velocity, or fatigue index.
benefits.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

benefits.title: Effects of creatine supplementation on cognitive function of healthy individuals: A systematic review of randomized controlled trials
benefits.summary: Oral creatine administration may improve short-term memory and intelligence/reasoning of healthy individuals, suggesting potential benefits for aging and stressed individuals.

benefits.title: International Society of Sports Nutrition position stand: safety and efficacy of creatine supplementation in exercise, sport, and medicine
benefits.summary: Creatine supplementation may enhance exercise performance, injury prevention, thermoregulation, rehabilitation, and neuroprotection.
benefits.journal: Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition

benefits.title: Clinical pharmacology of the dietary supplement creatine monohydrate.
benefits.summary: Creatine supplementation can improve exercise performance, reduce fatigue, and increase muscle mass in athletes.

benefits.title: Creatine supplementation with specific view to exercise/sports performance: an update
benefits.summary: Creatine supplementation increases strength, fat-free mass, and muscle morphology with concurrent heavy resistance training, promoting greater training adaptations.
benefits.journal: Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition

benefits.title: Creatine Supplementation: Its Effect on Human Muscular Performance and Body Composition
benefits.summary: Creatine monohydrate supplementation increases power output during high-intensity exercise, enhances muscle endurance, and may increase body mass.
benefits.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

benefits.title: Creatine supplementation in health and disease. Effects of chronic creatine ingestion in vivo: down-regulation of the expression of creatine transporter isoforms in skeletal muscle
benefits.summary: Creatine supplementation leads to exercise enhancement, especially in sprint performance, and shortens recovery periods after physical exercise.

benefits.title: Potential benefits of creatine monohydrate supplementation in the elderly
benefits.summary: Creatine monohydrate supplementation increases muscle total and phosphocreatine concentration, fat-free mass, and enhances high-intensity exercise performance in young healthy individuals.
benefits.journal: Current Opinion in Clinical Nutrition and Metabolic Care

benefits.title: A review of creatine supplementation in age-related diseases: more than a supplement for athletes
benefits.summary: Creatine may be important in preventing or delaying the onset of neurodegenerative diseases associated with aging, improving cognitive functions, and reducing mental fatigue.

side effects.title: The effect of creatine supplementation upon inflammatory and muscle soreness markers after a 30km race.
side effects.summary: Creatine supplementation reduced cell damage and inflammation after an intense race without side effects like cramping, dehydration, or diarrhea.

side effects.title: Potential Side Effects of Oral Creatine Supplementation: A Critical Review
side effects.summary: Oral creatine supplementation results in weight gain due to water retention, which may impede performance in mass-dependent activities like running and swimming.

side effects.title: Creatine: are the benefits worth the risk?
side effects.summary: Negative reports of creatine side effects include muscle cramping during exercise and potential impurities.

side effects.title: Potential cytotoxic effect of chronic administration of creatine, a nutrition supplement to augment athletic performance.
side effects.summary: Chronic creatine administration can increase the production of formaldehyde, which may potentially cause serious unwanted side-effects.

side effects.title: Acute renal failure in a young weight lifter taking multiple food supplements, including creatine monohydrate.
side effects.summary: Creatine use has been associated with renal dysfunction, including acute interstitial nephritis, in some cases.
side effects.journal: Journal of renal nutrition : the official journal of the Council on Renal Nutrition of the National Kidney Foundation

side effects.title: Oral creatine supplementation: separating fact from hype.
side effects.summary: Common side effects of creatine include muscle cramping, GI disturbances, and renal dysfunction.

side effects.title: Safety of creatine supplementation.
side effects.summary: Creatine is well-tolerated in most individuals in short-term studies, but isolated reports suggest it may be associated with side effects affecting skeletal muscle, kidney, and gastrointestinal tract.

side effects.title: Long-term creatine supplementation is safe in aged patients with Parkinson disease.
side effects.summary: Creatine supplementation in aged Parkinson's disease patients was well tolerated, with main side effects being gastrointestinal complaints.

side effects.title: Creatine supplementation improves muscular performance in older women
side effects.summary: Creatine supplementation increased strength, power, and lower-body motor functional performance in older women without any adverse side effects.

side effects.title: Effects of Creatine Supplementation on Exercise Performance
side effects.summary: Creatine supplementation may cause a small increase in body mass due to water retention or increased protein synthesis.

dosage.title: Creatine supplementation does not improve sprint performance in competitive swimmers.
dosage.summary: Creatine supplementation (5g creatine monohydrate 4 times per day for 5 days) did not improve sprint performance in highly trained swimmers.
dosage.journal: Medicine and science in sports and exercise

dosage.title: Acute creatine supplementation and performance during a field test simulating match play in elite female soccer players.
dosage.summary: Acute creatine supplementation (5g per day for 6 days) improved performance of some repeated sprint and agility tasks simulating soccer match play.
dosage.journal: International journal of sport nutrition and exercise metabolism

dosage.title: Creatine supplementation improves sprint performance in male sprinters
dosage.summary: Creatine supplementation in this study involved 20 g creatine+20 g glucose per day, divided into 4 equal dosages.
dosage.journal: Scandinavian Journal of Medicine & Science in Sports

dosage.title: Plasma guanidino compounds are altered by oral creatine supplementation in healthy humans.
dosage.summary: Oral creatine supplementation at a dosage of 20 g/day for the first week and 5 g/day for 19 subsequent weeks reduced plasma guanidinoacetate levels by 50%.

dosage.title: Effects of Varying Dosages of Oral Creatine Relative to Fat Free Body Mass on Strength and Body Composition
dosage.summary: Ingestion of 100 or 300 mg * kg1 FFM of creatine for 8 weeks in conjunction with weight training and speed training significantly improved 40-yd dash time and bench press strength, respectively.
dosage.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

dosage.title: The Effect of 7 Days of Creatine Supplementation on 24‐Hour Urinary Creatine Excretion
dosage.summary: Creatine dosage in this study was 0.1 gkg1 lean body mass, or between 6 and 8 g at a time.
dosage.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

dosage.title: Meta-Analysis Examining the Importance of Creatine Ingestion Strategies on Lean Tissue Mass and Strength in Older Adults
dosage.summary: Creatine-loading followed by lower-dose creatine (5 g/day) increased chest press strength, while higher-dose creatine (>5 g/day) produced significant gains in leg press strength.

dosage.title: Creatine supplementation in endurance sports.
dosage.summary: Creatine supplementation at doses of 6 g daily has positive effects on short-term exercise included in aerobic endurance exercise.
dosage.journal: Medicine and science in sports and exercise

dosage.title: Oral Creatine Supplementation and Skeletal Muscle Metabolism in Physical Exercise
dosage.summary: An effective creatine supplementation scheme is a dosage of 20 g/day for 4–6 days, and 5 g/day thereafter.

dosage.title: Changes of tissue creatine concentrations upon oral supplementation of creatine-monohydrate in various animal species.
dosage.summary: Oral creatine-monohydrate supplementation (1.3-2 g/kg/d; 1.4-2.8% of dietary intake) for 2-8 weeks significantly augmented creatine concentrations in various organs.
